item.title: What is Hemlock House about?
item.dc:creator: lkmsoule
item.content:encoded: Hemlock House is a collection of home/yard/craft projects, many of which are perpetual works-in-progress. This is a photo-album about stuff that I do and create. I’m primarily a doer and a maker-of-things. So, if things are quiet on my end for periods of time, it’s only because I’m out doing things (or otherwise just busy with the day-job). Whatever it is I’m doing, you’ll probably hear about it soon. Cheers!

item.title: About me
item.dc:creator: lkmsoule
item.content:encoded: I am a nest-featherer and (wannabe) house-fairy trying to build and maintain a pleasant and nurturing place to live, physically and psychic-ly. My interests lean towards a hodgepodge of creative and mostly unserious endeavors, especially those relating to food, landscaping and plants, clothes, visual arts, clutter-control, jewelry and stories with happy endings, all of which I try to enjoy as much as as possible outside of my full-time job. By day, I'm a communications manager for a local professional association, where I get to write, design, plan projects, and create spreadsheets to my heart's delight. Read more about my professional pursuits. Enjoy the site!  -Laura [caption id="attachment_505" align="alignnone" width="202"] Hard at work getting these albums together...[/caption]

item.title: Welcome!
item.dc:creator: lkmsoule
item.content:encoded: Thank you for visiting Hemlock House, which celebrates the big and small things that enrich our domestic lives. This initially covered home improvement projects and yard clean-up, but I've recently added sections for fashion design and photos. Here you can browse through some recent renovation and garden projects my husband Owen & I have been working on since March 2011. Our projects included the installation of new hardwood flooring, wallpaper removal/plaster repair, drywall, and priming/painting, as well as several efforts to tame the weeds in the backyard. Take a look at some of my costume creations, which are helping me refine my sewing skills. Enjoy and thanks for checking out the work the work at Hemlock. All hail the active imagination! Above: Gigantic koi at Chanticleer in Wayne, PA

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: My family always say that I am killing my time here at net, however I know I am getting familiarity every day by reading thes fastidious articles or reviews.

item.title: IMG_1174
item.dc:creator: lkmsoule
item.excerpt:encoded: Simplicity 2331 pattern for mystic costume

item.title: Pattern 3723
item.dc:creator: lkmsoule
item.excerpt:encoded: Simplicity 3723 - Amazing how just a few variations on a theme can span the centuries

item.title: IMG_1176
item.dc:creator: lkmsoule
item.excerpt:encoded: Simplicity pattern 5359 for dancers; both of these gave great results and really allows you to play with color & texture

item.title: IMG_1177
item.dc:creator: lkmsoule
item.excerpt:encoded: Simplicity pattern #2172 - By far the most technical of the patterns I've tried yet

item.title: IMG_0599
item.dc:creator: lkmsoule
item.excerpt:encoded: Here's a blue & gold version

item.title: IMG_0603
item.dc:creator: lkmsoule
item.excerpt:encoded: The inspiration first hit with this charming Elvis Vermont Teddy Bear my husband gave me when we were first dating. In taking a look at the jumpsuit here, I began to take a few measurements....

item.title: IMG_0607
item.dc:creator: lkmsoule
item.excerpt:encoded: Second variation on the gypsy costume with a bit more contrast in the colors. After Elvis, this became my personal favorite

item.title: IMG_0614
item.dc:creator: lkmsoule
item.excerpt:encoded: Remember that gypsy costume you saw in the earlier post? This was adapted from Simplicity patterns 2331 & 5359.

item.title: IMG_0621
item.dc:creator: lkmsoule
item.excerpt:encoded: And from there, I took some of the Simplicity patterns (this is based on #3723) and adapted them to bear size.

item.title: IMG_0627
item.dc:creator: lkmsoule
item.excerpt:encoded: Another view

item.title: IMG_0630
item.dc:creator: lkmsoule
item.excerpt:encoded: Complete costume from pattern 5359

item.title: IMG_0638
item.dc:creator: lkmsoule
item.excerpt:encoded: Hard at work getting these albums together...

item.title: IMG_0620
item.dc:creator: lkmsoule
item.excerpt:encoded: Sam the cat keeping me company

item.title: IMG_0632
item.dc:creator: lkmsoule
item.excerpt:encoded: Another version of 2331

item.title: IMG_0635
item.dc:creator: lkmsoule
item.excerpt:encoded: Adaptation of pattern 2331; These corset-belt things are a bit of a challenge but worth the effort

item.title: IMG_0610
item.dc:creator: lkmsoule
item.excerpt:encoded: Another take on that colonial costume. This took a bit of trial and error to get the fit right.

item.title: IMG_0641
item.dc:creator: lkmsoule
item.excerpt:encoded: Gotta get more bears! These are truly great for stress relief - Just looking at them cheers me up.

item.title: Moss agate necklace 2
item.dc:creator: lkmsoule
item.excerpt:encoded: Another pendant made of moss agate. This pattern looks treetops against a grey, stormy sky. Also includes black glass and Swarosvski glass 'pearls' (color is 'bordeaux')

item.title: Cameo necklace 2
item.dc:creator: lkmsoule
item.excerpt:encoded: another piece I ddin't make myself but wanted to share

item.title: Citrine necklace
item.dc:creator: lkmsoule
item.excerpt:encoded: Includes citrine, grey glass tiger eye, and Swarovski glass pearls in 'Night Blue'.

item.title: Mary pendant
item.dc:creator: lkmsoule
item.excerpt:encoded: I didn't make this pendant, but it's one of my favorite pieces and just wanted to share it: My grandmother went to Medugorje (Boznia & Herzogovina) in the mid 80s for a pilgrimage and brought this back for me. It reminds me to never stop believing in miracles.

item.title: Seed bead necklace
item.dc:creator: lkmsoule
item.excerpt:encoded: Includes Chocos Cariados seeds (aka Yinyan seeds) from South America, red/black plastic, red glass, and a pendant made of red coral pieces.

item.title: Gold shell pendant
item.dc:creator: lkmsoule
item.excerpt:encoded: You might recognize this pendant - this is one of the famous pieces sold at the Metropolitan Museum of Art store - it's a reproduction of something they have in their Egyptian collection. Here, I've added lapis lazuli and carnelian beads.

item.title: 18" smokey quartz necklace
item.dc:creator: lkmsoule
item.excerpt:encoded: This is kind of heavy to wear but I love the drama of these tumbled smokey quartz stones. It's of my favorite cold-weather pieces.

item.title: Beaded pin pendant
item.dc:creator: lkmsoule
item.excerpt:encoded: This pendant was also a pin that I converted into a pendant. Includes pink tiger eye glass beads, potato pearls, & plastic beads

item.title: Mosaic neclace
item.dc:creator: lkmsoule
item.excerpt:encoded: Mosaic pin, about 1" in diameter. I removed the pin hardware and converted this into a pendant.

item.title: Turquoise pendant
item.dc:creator: lkmsoule
item.excerpt:encoded: Turquoise pendant with amethyst, blue agate, hematite, and chrysocolla beads

item.title: Closeup of pendant
item.dc:creator: lkmsoule
item.excerpt:encoded: Closeup of moss agate pendant. I absolutely love moss agate - Each stone looks like a mini-landscape

item.title: 18" necklace with moonstone, carnelian
item.dc:creator: lkmsoule
item.excerpt:encoded: Other view of moonstone/carnelian necklace

item.title: 18" necklace with moonstone, carnelian
item.dc:creator: lkmsoule
item.excerpt:encoded: Moonstone, carnelian, tiny yellow jade beads

item.title: Jadite necklace
item.dc:creator: lkmsoule
item.excerpt:encoded: Jade/Jadeite pendant with aventurine, kyanite, flourite beads

item.title: Moss agate neclace
item.dc:creator: lkmsoule
item.excerpt:encoded: Moss agate pendant with silver, carnelian, striped agate, plastic black beads

item.title: 20" necklace with moonstone
item.dc:creator: lkmsoule
item.excerpt:encoded: Moonstone, blue lace agate, carnelian

item.title: Asymmetrical design
item.dc:creator: lkmsoule
item.excerpt:encoded: This turned out to be my favorite for its animated look. I may do some other variations on this pattern.

item.title: Various tests of pattens
item.dc:creator: lkmsoule
item.excerpt:encoded: Here's a collection of different trials where I experimented with arm length, head size, & leg shape

item.title: Batwing arm design
item.dc:creator: lkmsoule
item.excerpt:encoded: One of the earlier prototypes - The arms are a bit too angled, I think.

item.title: Patchwork doll
item.dc:creator: lkmsoule
item.excerpt:encoded: I consider this one of the winners - the patched fabric adds a neat effect and is a good substitute for actual clothes

item.title: Wedding
item.dc:creator: lkmsoule
item.content:encoded: Laura and Owen's Wedding
item.excerpt:encoded: The 'costume' worked great as a wedding dress :-)

item.dc:creator: lkmsoule
item.content:encoded: View more at HemlockHut.com
item.excerpt:encoded: This is a former exhibit building at the N.C. Museum of Life and Science that was converted into a picnic pavilion. I loved the juxtaposition between the sharp angles of the building against the rugged pine trees.

item.excerpt:encoded: UNC has one of the most beautiful campuses in the country. The Davis Library is particularly interesting because of the multiple levels and big windows.

item.title: Holden Beach Clouds (North Carolina)
item.dc:creator: lkmsoule
item.content:encoded: More available at www.HemlockHut.com
item.excerpt:encoded: Holden Beach has long been a favorite family vacation spot and is unusual in that the beach faces south instead of east.

item.title: Interior renovation: Plaster repair and paint galore
item.dc:creator: lkmsoule
item.content:encoded:
During the spring and summer of 2011 we started to repair the plaster (walls and ceilings) and started to paint. ALL of the walls and ceilings were in need of repair and paint - this was not what you'd call an out-of-the-box house!
[gallery]

item.title: The fun begins on our new house
item.dc:creator: lkmsoule
item.content:encoded:
In March 2011 we bought our first home, a Tudor revival number in need of some serious TLC. The first phase involved repairing the floors, many of which were completely destroyed (due to years of previous feline activity).
[gallery]

item.title: The scary basement becomes a gym and some first floor projects
item.dc:creator: lkmsoule
item.content:encoded:
During January through March 2012, we tackled the cracked plaster in the living and dining room, and sealed the walls in the basement.
[gallery]

item.title: Greenhouse removal
item.dc:creator: lkmsoule
item.content:encoded:
In March, 2012 we rented a huge dumpster, invited some sturdy friends and family members, and dismantled the deck and the greenhouse that had been attached to the back of the house. Now we have a brick patio.
[gallery]

item.title: Cleaning up Spider Yard
item.dc:creator: lkmsoule
item.content:encoded:
I called the southeast corner of the lot "Spider Yard" because of the piles and piles of bricks, flagstones, random rocks, and pavers that had been sitting for years, probably, and as a result were transformed into spider luxury-condos. Seeing the hardscaping possibilities, I was determined to use every single brick and stone possible to give some definition to the then overgrown yard.
[gallery]

item.title: Plume poppy insanity
item.dc:creator: lkmsoule
item.content:encoded:
Have you seen these exotic-looking, gigantic-leaved plants with seeds at the top known as plume poppies? I don't really see these anywhere except in my yard, but boy, are they annoyingly profuse. There was a large forest of them in an area I wanted to make into a more 'respectable' flower bed, so I had to dig the stubborn things out.
You'll see that some of the rocks and pavers that were sitting in Spider Yard were put to good use!
[gallery ids="292,293,291,297,296,294,298,453,449,448,450,451"]

item.title: What a difference a little mulch makes
item.dc:creator: lkmsoule
item.content:encoded:
In the side bed, part of the stone wall was crumbling, and some random rocks were piled up on one end. Owen was able to patch the wall back together and then tidied up the area with some mulch.
[gallery]

item.title: Defining the cherry beds
item.dc:creator: lkmsoule
item.content:encoded:
I call them the cherry beds only because there's a large black cherry tree growing nearby. This was another out-of-control jungle I attempted to tame.
[gallery]

item.title: Pond clean-out
item.dc:creator: lkmsoule
item.content:encoded:
The pond had accumulated a LOT of leaves over the years and hadn't been cleaned out since we-don't-know-when. So it was time just deal with it already. Having a heavy-duty water pump was really helpful and got the water out pretty fast. With an extra long hose, we just drained it into different areas of the yard.
Towards the bottom, I switched to the shop vac since there was no water left, only really thick muck. The pond has been refilled and the frogs are happy.
[gallery]

item.title: Back porch clean up
item.dc:creator: lkmsoule
item.content:encoded: By far one of the coolest rooms in the house, the enclosed back porch was still a bit rustic-looking and needed some sprucing. The built in cabinet had an odd hole underneath that seemed to be the perfect through-way between the outdoors and the basement - I'm sure the mice loved it for their winter home. Not shown in the photos, there is now about 500 lbs of solid concrete where the hole used to be.[gallery ids="402,392,401,393,396,395,397,398,400,399,394,404,390,403,391"]

item.title: In the kitchen
item.dc:creator: lkmsoule
item.content:encoded: At long last we have been able to scrape out some time to refurbish that room where so much important stuff happens - It's where we greet our loved ones, find nourishment, gather our wits before heading out to face the world, and store our dirty shoes: The kitchen.[gallery ids="422,418,419,253,425,416,420,415,414"]

item.title: Steampunk express
item.dc:creator: lkmsoule
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_599" align="alignnone" width="200"] Another version - The red fabric is shantung and the coat is brocade paisley[/caption] [gallery ids="483,468,466,472"]

item.title: Teddy bear outfits based on costume patterns
item.dc:creator: lkmsoule

item.title: Blue voodoo for you
item.dc:creator: lkmsoule
item.content:encoded:
A few weeks ago I came up idea of making a voodoo doll as a good 'ol fashioned tool of catharsis (we all need an outlet now and again, right?) I remembered the adorable 'Dammit Dolls' (dammitdolls.com) I first saw during a visit to Hex in Salem, Mass., which had the perfect combination of plushness and durability. After finding a variety of voodoo doll patterns & ideas online, I got to work.
Oddly enough, after making a couple of these, I found myself wanting to hug them instead of beat them. Even though I tried to make them extra ugly, I just knew these wouldn't be seeing any angry pin-pricking sessions. Hence, I've decided to call these my 'blue voodoo' dolls. Why blue? The color blue is believed to exude soothing, healing energy. Even though these have very little blue in them, they still carry a healthy, positive vibe. I'd like to believe so, anyway! :-)
[gallery ids="550,552,551,549"]

item.title: From the jewelry box
item.dc:creator: lkmsoule
item.content:encoded:
I'm a huge fan of jewelry and have had lots of fun stringing beads and collecting pendants over the years. Below is a sampling from my collection:
[gallery ids="548,547,543,546,545,544,542,541,540,539,538,537,536,535,534"]

item.title: Hemlock Hut Artworks
item.dc:creator: lkmsoule
item.content:encoded:
I finally opened up an Etsy store, which is something I'd been wanting to do for a while as a way to showcase some of the original artwork I have stashed away. In putting everything together and getting pics of all the various drawing, paintings, and prints, I had the chance to revisit some of my favorite places around North Carolina and the Tuscan countryside.  View the full collection at:

www.HemlockHut.com

Here's a sampling! Museum of Life and Science that was converted into a picnic pavilion. I loved the juxtaposition between the sharp angles of the building against the rugged pine trees.[/caption] [caption id="attachment_592" align="aligncenter" width="211" class=" "] This is one of several studies I did of the various trees and landscapes in the Tuscan region of Italy.[/caption] [caption id="attachment_591" align="aligncenter" width="207" class=" "] This is a print of an original watercolor depicting two loblolly pine tree trunks. Loblolly pines are all over North Carolina.[/caption] [caption id="attachment_590" align="aligncenter" width="222" class=" "] This is a print of an original color pencil drawing of a pond and the shady path beyond.
